author: Anonymous Poet
title: Enumeration and Itemization Definitions
question:
Hi, 
I just wanted to clarify what enumeration and itemization means. 
Definitions from the design recipe,
Enumeration: 
consists of a fixed number of distinct items (one-of several strings)
Itemization:
is comprised of 2 or more subclasses, at least one of which is not a distinct item
Also, in the design recipe: 
Note that in a mixed data itemization, such as
;; Measurement is one of:</kbd>
<kbd>;; - "high"</kbd>
<kbd>;; - "low"</kbd>
<kbd>;; - false
Why is this example considered a (mixed data) itemization and not an enumeration if all of the items are distinct (strings and false are both distinct)? Doesn't itemization requires at least 1 non-distinct item?
And does an enumeration require all items to be strings or can an enumeration contain other distinct items (such as false, empty, etc)? 
Thank you!
instructor_answer:
That example in the DR pages has been troublesome for some time. Thanks for reminding us.  I now changed it to a more clear itemization.
You may have to ctl- or shift- refresh to get your browser to pull down the new page.
